Award.AwardTitle: Testing the Statistical Isotropy of the Universe
Award.AbstractNarration:
Dr. Huterer will study statistical isotropy of the universe on its largest scales, following on other recent studies that indicate that the underlying sky in the cosmic microwave background observations is not statistically isotropic. Traditional approaches for extracting cosmological parameters would be invalid if the universe is not isotropic, requiring new techniques for estimation. The funded research will study the distribution of galaxies and other sources in surveys covering wavelengths from radio to gamma-ray, and will complement the traditional studies based on previous satellite observations. An alternative representation of cosmological perturbations on the sky using multipole vectors will be used for tests of alignments and isotropy in the large-scale structure and cosmic microwave background data.

Broader impacts of this work will include an education/outreach program aimed at tutoring teachers, and involvement with the Exhibit Museum (and planetarium) of National History in Ann Arbor to introduce cosmology exhibits and increase visibility of this institution in the wider Detroit metro area.

POR.DRECONTENT:
How does the Universe look on its largest observable scales?  In other words, if we could smooth out the distribution of all objects in our observable universe, what would we observe? Would we see a giant pancake, or perhaps a sausage, and in which direction would this object be pointing? Answering this question and mapping out the largest observable structures in the universe is one of the main goals of modern cosmology.  But until relatively recently, we lacked a map of the universe that covers scales (distances) that are large enough.

The Wilkinson Microwave Anisotropy Probe (WMAP) space telescope has provided just such a map of the cosmic microwave background (CMB) anisotropies -- radiation left over from the Big Bang. WMAP has been publishing remarkable results since 2003 and has helped revolutionize our understanding of the universe.  Dragan Huterer (University of Michigan), together with Craig Copi, Glenn Starkman and Dominik Schwarz, analyzed the WMAP data using a novel formalism to describe the CMB temperature anisotropy which they previously developed.  They discovered an entirely unexpected new structure in the CMB pattern on the largest observable scales. In particular, they found that the largest observable structures in the universe lie approximately in one plane, and that this plane is nearly perpendicular to the ecliptic plane -- the trajectory of the Sun.  The probability of these alignments is much less than one percent. Given these findings and similar ones found by other groups, it is clear that largest structures in the universe deserve to be investigated in more detail.
 
In work funded by the NSF, Huterer and collaborators further investigated the structure of the universe on its largest scales. In addition to further analyzing the CMB maps measured by the WMAP experiment, they studied how the distribution of galaxies  in  the sky can be used to confirm, and better understand, alignments found in the CMB data. Several galaxy surveys that are coming on line this decade will be much larger (in volume of the universe that they observe) than any observations done previously. These surveys will be perfectly suited to studying the fundamental physical processes on large scales. The research of Huterer and collaborators elucidated how to best utilize this complementarity between the CMB temperature fluctuations and the observed galaxy distribution to learn about the universe on its largest observable scales.
